messageBody:
I'll take the first question and leave number two for someone clever. :-)

On Thu, 10 Feb 2005 12:16:03 +0200, Pico Geyer <picog@...> wrote:
>
> Hi
>
> I'm a little confused on how to test certain types of methods.
> Is JUnit supposed to be able to test all types of methods.
>
> For example how do you test a:
> 1) Method that only modifies private fields and has no corresponding
> getter method to see if the field is now at the correct value

This is easy ... you test the effects. If there are no effects, then
why do you have the method? To use your example: what is the secondary
effect of setting the private fields? The primary effect will be that
the private fields get new values. That these values are not available
with getters is not necessarily a problem. If the new values in the
fields have secondary effects, then measure those. Ask yourself why
you are setting these private fields and then test the thing that they
do affect.

Let's make up a contrived example. Perhaps in a sales system, you can
generate quotes with different customer discounts. Let's pretend that
the discount is our "set only" field. So we can set it's value but not
inspect it. Fine. The reason that we have the field is to calculate
discounts on quotes. So, to test it, set a sale price of $100, set the
discount at 10% and check that the quote gives you an answer of $90.
The affect on the quoted price is the secondary effect. If there is no
secondary effect of the method, then I strongly suggest that it needs
very close examination. :-)

> 2) Methods that work on network traffic, ex counting all TCP packets
> that I receive. I would need an isolated environment and would need to
> be able to send X amount of packets to my machine.
>
> Thanks in advance
> Pico

Hope this helps.
